IMAGING: 
========
CT CHEST with contrast (___)
1. Recurrence of consolidations more prominent in the right lung 
base since the ___ study, suggestive of worsening 
infection. 
2. Stable post radiotherapy changes in the left paramediastinal 
location. 
3. Unchanged aspect of a consolidation at the anterior left 
lower lobe.  To be followed in ___ week as previously

4. Stable right hilar lymphadenopathy.  Mild increase in the 
left pleural

Video Swallow Study (___)
IMPRESSION:  
No aspiration.  Penetration with thin liquids. 

Swallow assessment (___)
Patient presents with functional, safe, and efficient
oropharyngeal swallowing. There was trace, transient penetration
with thin liquids and no visualization of aspiration; this is
considered WFL. There was just trace post-swallow pharyngeal
residue. Of note, there was no evidence of an anterior 
protrusion
at the entrance of the esophagus - as seen in ___ - indicating
that this narrowing has likely resolved spontaneously. Based on
these results, it is not suspected that oropharyngeal swallowing
dysfunction is the cause of patient's recurrent pneumonias.

The patient did present with esophageal retention and retrograde
flow of liquid and solid contrast in the esophagus; this raises
concern for esophageal dysfunction, such as dysmotility or a
structural issue. This may place patient at risk for
post-prandial aspiration with potential for pneumonia. 
Esophageal
dysfunction may be a side effect of prior lung cancer radiation
treatment. It is recommended that she return to visit a GI
specialist for further work-up and management of suspected
esophageal dysfunction.

ACUTE ISSUES: 
=============
#Dyspnea
#Recurrent PNA 
#hx radiation esophagitis 
Pt presenting with worsening dyspnea, new productive cough and 
leukocytosis
concerning for recurrent PNA, which CT redemonstrated on 
admission. Dyspnea was felt not to be related to pt's HFpEF 
given no evidence of on volume exam or imaging. She was treated 
broadly for HAP coverage given recent antibiotic use (including 
levaquin in ___ - she completed a 7 day course of cefepime 
___. Given concern for aspiration as cause for recurrent 
PNA, especially given patient's history of radiation 
esophagitis, she underwent a video swallow study which showed no 
signs of oropharyngeal pathology or aspiration - but did show 
evidence of distal esophageal dysmotility which may increase 
patient's risk for reflux and silent aspiration and/or nocturnal 
aspiration. Pulmonology was consulted for question of whether 
recurrent PNA may be due to post-obstructive cause such as a 
mass - but on review of imaging with thoracics radiology there 
was not any identifiable mass thought to contribute to this. 
There is a possibility that a component of dyspnea may be 
related to a restrictive process given patient's history of 
radiation and pericardial effusions. She improved while 
receiving 7d course of cefepime and will have pulmonary follow 
up at ___ in ___ weeks with repeat CT chest at that time. 
She may benefit from bronchoscopy in the near-term if she has 
another recurrence.
